data.title: Opening a New project in a new window causes editor crash
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [ ] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [ ] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [ ] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [ ] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [ ] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.

### Description

I could successfully open a project in atom. But when i tried to open a new project in a new window, it causes the editor to crash.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18014704/20192604/691ab552-a73f-11e6-9d6a-6c492012b47c.png)


[Description of the bug or feature]

### Steps to Reproduce

1. [First Step]
2. [Second Step]
3. [and so on...]

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

data.title: Viewing "Install / Atom Chrome" causes editor to crash
data.body:
### Prerequisites
* [ ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
No. I also can't reproduce it with `--foreground`. I'm looking for information on how to diagnose this.
* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
Yes, 1.12.0.
* [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
Yes, it's the main editor that's crashing.
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
Yes, I don't see anything promising there.

### Description
When I look at the package description for `atomic-chrome` (not even trying to install it!), Atom crashes.
This is fairly reproducible under the specific conditions that:
* I start `atom` with no flags.
* I look at `atomic-chrome`.

It doesn't seem to happen with any other plugin about pages, and I can't find any logs (I looked in `~\.atom`, `~\atom`, my home folder, and Event Viewer under Windows Logs: Application). Also, `--log-file` doesn't actually seem to create a log file anywhere I can find.

### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open Settings.
2. Go to Install.
3. Click `atomic-chrome`.
4. Scroll up and down for a few seconds.

**Expected behavior:** It works normally.
**Actual behavior:** "Editor has crashed" dialog.

### Versions
Atom: 1.12.0
Windows 10 Pro 64-bit

data.title: RPM Install: error while loading shared libraries: libXss.so.1: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

### Description

Updated Atom by official RPM.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom.

**Expected behavior:** Atom opens

**Actual behavior:** `/usr/share/atom/atom: error while loading shared libraries: libXss.so.1: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory`

### Versions

`atom --version` returns nothing.

```
$ rpm -q atom
atom-1.12.0-0.1.x86_64

$ apm --version
apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4
```

Fedora 24 Linux 4.8.4-200.fc24.x86_64 #1 SMP Tue Oct 25 13:06:04 UTC 2016 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

### Workaround

```
$ pkcon install libXScrnSaver
```

... so, it seems this dependency is missing in last RPM.

data.title: Keystrokes involving ctrl on Linux resolve to the default layout instead of the active layout
data.body:
### Prerequisites

Atom 1.12beta7 on Debian Stretch (testing).

### Description

My keyboard is using Colemak. Shortcuts only work in their QWERTY positions.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Use Colemak layout
2. Open a file
3. Modify it
4. Try to save it via Colemak's Ctrl+S (which corresponds to the QWERTY position of Ctrl+D).

**Expected behavior:**
It should save the file (or prompt to save it as...)

**Actual behavior:**

It does not offer the options stated above.

** Workaround:**

Try to save it via QWERTY's Ctrl+S (which corresponds to the Colemak's position of Ctrl+R). It will work.


### Versions

Atom 1.12beta7 under Debian Stretch (testing).

data.title: Keymap copy-pase doesn't escape backslash
data.body:
I want to change the keybinding for "cmd-\\". The Settings say that I can override these keybindings by clicking on the copy button pasting them into your keymap file. When I do so for cmd-\\, this is what is pasted:

    '.platform-darwin':
      'cmd-\': 'tree-view:toggle'

However, when I go to save the file, it gives me an error: 

    Failed to load /Users/oscargarcia/.atom/keymap.cson
    [stdin]:38:29: error: missing '
      'cmd-\': 'tree-view:toggle'

The correct syntax is to escape the backslash like so:

    '.platform-darwin':
      'cmd-\\': 'tree-view:toggle'

This is a minor bug for an unusual use case, but I thought I would mention it.

Atom 1.11.2
OS X 10.11.6

data.title: Keymaps with same selector declared multiple times should produce an error popup
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [ y] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [y ] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [ y] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [ y] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [y ] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [ y] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.

### Description

Keymap.cson containing the same selector twice will silently fail to map all but the final one.  This is mentioned in a comment in the default version of the file, but having long ago replaced the entire contents of the file, it is easy to end up scratching your head wondering why your keymap is not working, and no error popup is generated.

At the very least a warning popup should appear when you save a keymap with the same selector twice, since there is no useful reason to have such a file.
 
### Steps to Reproduce

1. create a keymap with 

'.platform-darwin atom-workspace atom-text-editor':
  'shift-cmd-J': 'editor:move-line-up'

'.platform-darwin atom-workspace atom-text-editor':
  'shift-cmd-K': 'editor:move-line-down'

2. save

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
Warning or error popup.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

Silent failure.

### Versions
Atom    : 1.11.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

data.title: Frame drops and sluggishness with gSync
data.body:
### Description
Frame rate drops to 2-20 fps, slow to pick up when I start working again: feels sluggish and laggy. On gSync monitor. Similar to an issue in Visual Studio Code, except I don't have to fullscreen with Atom:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/5516
Like in VS Code, running atom --disable-gpu makes it work as expected.

### Steps to Reproduce
Have gSync enabled in windowed and full screen and open Atom.

**Expected behavior:** Fps to full refresh rate of monitor and high responsiveness.

**Actual behavior:** Frame rates as low as 2-20 fps when idle, slow to pick up when I start working again: feels sluggish and laggy.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.11.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

data.title: Shake Screen effect of Active Power Mode Package in Gnome Classic is not working
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [ yes] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [yes ] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [yes ] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [yes ] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [ no] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [yes ] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.

### Description

Shake Screen at Active Power Mode in Gnome Classic is not working

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Launch Ubuntu at Gnome Classic mode
2. Launch Atom
3. Install Active Power Mode Package
4. Notice that shake screen effect is not working

**Expected behavior:** 
Shake Screen is work well

**Actual behavior:** 
Shake Screen is not working

### Versions

Atom    : 1.11.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

Packages installed
├── activate-power-mode@1.1.0
